newsitem.title: USA: US Sen Daschle seeks agreement on USTR nominee.
newsitem.headline: US Sen Daschle seeks agreement on USTR nominee.

text.p: Senate Democratic Leader Tom Daschle of South Dakota said he hoped to reach agreement with Sen. Ernest Hollings on legislation needed to confirm Charlene Barshefsky as U.S. Trade Representative.
Because she worked for Canada before becoming deputy USTR, Congress must pass a bill waiving a law that bars those who have worked for foreign interests from becoming USTR.

Hollings, D-S.C., has said he will offer an amendment to the bill requiring congressional approval for any trade agreement negotiated under the World Trade Organization that alters U.S. trade law or practices.
Daschle and the Clinton administration would like Hollings to withdraw his amendment.
"I would hope we could resolve this. That (Hollings) amendment is not going to pass," Daschle told reporters. But he said the issue was still unresolved.
Barshefsky's nomination has been approved by the Senate Finance Committee and is awaiting action by the full Senate.
Both the House and Senate must pass the waiver bill but only Senate approval is needed to confirm Barshefsky's nomination. She has been acting USTR since last year.
